title: Sub Question 1
stimulusHtml:
2 points maximum
2 points: In order to receive any credit, both a correct figure of speech and correct Latin must be included in the answer. Minimal Latin underlined. Three possible answers: apostrophe—Improbe Amor; personification—Improbe Amor; synecdoche—pectora (with an appropriate explanation).
descriptions:
Student response earns none of the available points.

2 points: In order to receive any credit, both a correct figure of speech and correct Latin must be included in the answer. Minimal Latin underlined. Three possible answers: apostrophe—Improbe Amor; personification—Improbe Amor; synecdoche—pectora (with an appropriate explanation).

Student response earns one of the available points.

2 points: In order to receive any credit, both a correct figure of speech and correct Latin must be included in the answer. Minimal Latin underlined. Three possible answers: apostrophe—Improbe Amor; personification—Improbe Amor; synecdoche—pectora (with an appropriate explanation).

Student response earns two of the available points.

2 points: In order to receive any credit, both a correct figure of speech and correct Latin must be included in the answer. Minimal Latin underlined. Three possible answers: apostrophe—Improbe Amor; personification—Improbe Amor; synecdoche—pectora (with an appropriate explanation).

title: Sub Question 2
stimulusHtml:
3 points maximum

Identification (1 point):

1 point: Dido, Elissa, the queen of Carthage. Not required to be identified by name. Supplex is acceptable, but only if the word is translated.

Latin to support answer (2 points):

2 points: 1 point per action. Both the Latin words/phrase and a translation are required for each action. The identification may be contained in the translation. Three possible answers: Ire iterum in lacrimas (to go again into tears, to weep); iterum temptare precando (to try again by entreating); supplex animos summittere amori (as a suppliant to submit her pride to love).
